thread.title: London roundabout named as UK's most dangerous junction for cyclists | London Evening Standard
thread.title_full: London roundabout named as UK's most dangerous junction for cyclists | London Evening Standard

author: Tom Powell
title: London roundabout named as UK's most dangerous junction for cyclists | London Evening Standard
text:
Monday 13 February 2017 10:42 GMT Click to followThe Evening Standard Vigil: the 'die-in' protest held at the blackspot following a cyclist's death in 2015 
Britain’s worst cycling accident blackspot has been identified as the central London roundabout where a renowned art designer was knocked off her bike and killed. 
Moira Gemmill, 55, hand-picked by the Queen to oversee renovations at Windsor Castle, died after she was struck by a tipper truck on Millbank in 2015. 
The roundabout at the junction with Lambeth Bridge saw a total of 53 accidents involving cyclists between 2009 and 2015, according to an analysis of Department for Transport figures by Mapmechanics. 
There were 139,628 fatal cycling accidents on the country’s roads in the same period, according to the figures published in the Sunday Times . Hundreds of cyclists stage central London 'die in' over safety 
Eight of the 10 worst blackspots were revealed to be in London, although roads in Oxford and Cambridge were the second and third worst blackspots respectively. Moira Gemmill died in a collision at the Lambeth Bridge blackspot in 2015 
Kennington Park Road and Upper Tooting Road were the second most dangerous blackspots in London, witnessing 29 each. 10by2020 protest outside the Treasury on February 11 10by2020 protest outside the Treasury on February 11 1/9 
Cyclists stage a protest and 'die in' outside the Treasury Rex Features 
A 'die-in' vigil held outside the Treasury Stop Killing Cyclists 
Cyclist Roberto Sanchez holds up a banner outside the Treasury 4/9 
Children hold banners which read 'Taffic Stop Killing Our Cyclists' during a protest outside the Treasury 5/9 
A woman wears a pollution mask at the 10by2020 protest urging the Government to invest more in walking and cycling infastructure 6/9 
Activists listen to speeches at the 10by2020 protest 7/9 
Cyclists protest through central London on air pollution PA 
Cyclists protest through central London campaigning for safer roads in the capital PA 
Riders wheel their bikes along Whitehall towards the Treasury PA 
It comes after three cyclists died in just four days on London’s roads last week, prompting a mass “die-in” protest outside of Whitehall. Top five cycling blackspots 
1. Lambeth Bridge/Millbank roundabout, London - 53 
2. Iffley Road/Cowley Road roundabout, Oxford - 45 
3. Trumpington Road, Cambridge - 34 
4. Kennington Park Road, London - 29 
5. Upper Tooting Road, London - 29 
As well as paying tribute to those killed, campaigners demanded Chancellor Philip Hammond increases investment in the UK’s cycling and pedestrian infrastructure to 10 per cent of the transport budget. 
Saturday’s vigil saw cyclists lay down their bikes and drop onto the wet tarmac for a minute’s silence. 
Campaigner Nicole Branch said: “Five sets of families and friends are grieving at the moment and these deaths could have been avoided if this government would just invest in infrastructure. 'Devoted father': Ben Wales was killed while cycling in east London 
“This government needs to wake up and spend money on our infrastructure so that people stop being killed and so that families are not ripped apart by these awful incidents.” 
Afterwards, Ms Branch read out heartfelt tributes for cyclists Ben Wales and Karla Roman, both 32, and Anita Szucs, 30. Cyclist Karla Roman died in Whitechapel last week 
Devoted father Mr Wales, who was wearing a helmet and a high-visibility vest, was crushed to death by a 40-tonne tipper truck in Docklands on Thursday afternoon. 
Just three days earlier, cyclists Anita Szucs, 30, and Karla Roman, 32, were also killed in the space of just 24 hours in separate crashes in Enfield and Whitechapel on Monday. Anita Szucs, 30, suffered fatal injuries in a suspected hit-and-run 
A similar “die-in” protest was held at the Lambeth bridge blackspot in April 2015 following the death of Ms Gemmill as she was cycling to work at the V&A museum. Read more
